verses.text: I cry aloud to God; I cry out, and He will listen to me.
verses.comment: The psalm begins with a personal, persistent plea to God, emphasizing trust that God hears. This echoes earlier psalms and Job's lament, showing a traditional Jewish approach to bringing cares before the Lord.

verses.text: In the day of my trouble I sought the Lord. My hand was stretched out at night and did not grow weary; my soul refused to be comforted.
verses.comment: A picture of unresolved suffering and tireless prayer; highlighting that even devout people can face periods when God seems distant.

verses.text: When I remember God, I groan; when I meditate, my spirit grows faint. Selah.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s pain increases as he reflects on God’s ways, hinting at the mystery of suffering. The word 'Selah' is retained—a musical or liturgical pause; its meaning is debated.

verses.text: You hold my eyelids open; I am so troubled that I cannot speak.
verses.comment: The inability to sleep or speak shows how thorough suffering can silence and paralyze even the faithful—an experience not foreign to saints or Christ Himself (Matt. 26:38).

verses.text: I consider the days of old, the years long past.
verses.comment: Turning to the memories of God’s past faithfulness as a source of hope, echoing the importance of history and tradition in faith—parallels to Sacred Tradition in Catholic understanding.

verses.text: I remember my song in the night; I meditate within my heart, and my spirit makes a diligent search:
verses.comment: Night-time reflection recalls moments of deeper prayer and the use of song—prefiguring the tradition of liturgical prayers and hymns.

verses.text: Will the Lord reject forever? Will He never again show His favor?
verses.comment: Deep questions of abandonment reflect those asked by Christ on the Cross (Matt. 27:46). Such questions reveal vulnerability and honesty in prayer.

verses.text: Has His steadfast love ceased forever? Are His promises at an end for all generations?
verses.comment: 'Steadfast love' translates 'hesed'—God’s covenantal mercy. The psalmist’s doubt shows the human side of faith, wrestling with the promises of God, later fulfilled in Christ, the New Covenant.

verses.text: Has God forgotten to be gracious? Has He in anger shut up His compassion? Selah.
verses.comment: God’s graciousness (grace) and compassion are questioned—a theme that recurs in Israel’s doubts. The word 'Selah' again invites contemplation.

verses.text: Then I said, 'It is my grief, that the right hand of the Most High has changed.'
verses.comment: "The right hand of the Most High" is a biblical symbol for God’s power—Saints and the Church understand God’s apparent silence as a test for steadfast faith.

verses.text: I will remember the deeds of the Lord; yes, I will remember your wonders of old.
verses.comment: Remembrance of God’s works is a recurring theme. In a Catholic context, this foreshadows the Eucharist, which is the memorial of Christ’s Paschal Mystery, fulfilled in the New Covenant.

verses.text: I will meditate on all your work and consider your mighty deeds.
verses.comment: The practice of meditation is encouraged in both Jewish and Christian tradition; the pondering of God’s works is central to spiritual life.

verses.text: Your way, O God, is holy. What god is as great as our God?
verses.comment: The uniqueness and transcendence of God are declared. The rhetorical question is later fulfilled in Christ, who reveals God’s true holiness.

verses.text: You are the God who works wonders; you have made your power known among the peoples.
verses.comment: God’s works make His presence known to all nations—a prophecy ultimately completed in Christ and through the universal Church.

verses.text: You with your arm redeemed your people, the children of Jacob and Joseph. Selah.
verses.comment: Redemption is central. The rescuing of Israel prefigures the final redemption in Christ. 'Selah' again marks a pause for meditation.

verses.text: When the waters saw you, O God, when the waters saw you, they trembled; the depths also shook.
verses.comment: Poetic language describing the crossing of the Red Sea—a clear typology foreshadowing Christian baptism, which Paul explicitly references (1 Cor. 10:1-2).

verses.text: The clouds poured out water; the skies gave forth thunder; your arrows flashed on every side.
verses.comment: Thunder and lightning are frequently used as images of God’s power and revelation, connected with Sinai and Theophany.

verses.text: The sound of your thunder was in the whirlwind; your lightning lit up the world; the earth trembled and shook.
verses.comment: Describes Sinai, theophany, and the awe-inspiring presence of God—a connection to God’s revelation to His people and, spiritually, to how God’s presence still stirs the world.

verses.text: Your way was through the sea, your path through the great waters; yet your footprints were unseen.
verses.comment: God’s mysterious guidance—He leads even when we cannot see Him, analogous to divine Providence and Christ’s presence in the Sacraments.

verses.text: You led your people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
verses.comment: The closing verse uses shepherd imagery, foundational for Christ’s declaration 'I am the Good Shepherd' (John 10:11). Moses and Aaron prefigure Christ's role as High Priest—recall the importance of priestly mediation in Catholic faith.
